stream_context.summary: Kaze prototypes and plans the visual style and layout for Course 12, a new Wild West/cowboy-themed level. He refines the mission concepts (three outlaw boss encounters that end with jailing the culprits), explores references and AI concept art to find a “goofy cowboy town” palette, and discovers that adding a skybox/fog dramatically improves the look. He also discusses technical tradeoffs: fog forces expensive 2‑cycle materials (as seen previously in Oily Boily Bay), and he outlines a layout choice (a town wrapped around a central mountain) to improve N64 culling/performance. Badub messages Kaze mid-stream with a new track that influences the level’s atmosphere decisions (fog/ambience).
stream_context.significance_reason: Strong reveal of Course 12’s core design pitch (train traversal + three ‘outlaw’ bosses jailed as stars), a concrete production workflow/timeline, and a key visual breakthrough (skybox first) plus an important technical constraint (fog requires 2‑cycle materials, likely hurting performance).

findings.summary: Course 12 is a Western/cowboy town stage built as a canyon valley with buildings embedded along canyon walls and vertical traversal to higher areas; it includes a saloon (milk-only gag), sheriff/jail, bank, cowboy head shop, train tracks, and a gold mine as a major set piece.

The level’s core mission structure in the town centers on capturing three ‘outlaw’ mini-bosses; each boss yields a star and ends with the culprit being put in jail, framing the whole course as a comedic lawman roleplay.

Planned boss/mission concepts: (1) a saloon secret-room shootout with a Snufit outlaw; (2) a bank robbery solved by following a continuous Monty Mole digging trail to a hideout and boss fight; (3) a train robbery mystery where a tall trench-coat Goomba (actually five Goombas stacked) is toppled to trigger a multi-Goomba shootout using cork-gun props.

A moving train is a guaranteed feature: two stations allow fast travel between Area 1 (town) and Area 3 (train HQ), and Kaze also wants a train with strong visual presence (e.g., passing over Mario near the start) to sell the theme and set tone immediately.
Kaze formalizes a workflow for building the course: pick building art style → draw overhead map (MS Paint) → blockout → beautify/polish.
Kaze uses the Mario 64 decomp + Blender/Fast64 workflow to export levels; he notes he no longer has tutorial videos because Nintendo removed/took down his tutorials.
findings.quote: I don’t explain this anywhere. Nintendo took all my tutorials down.

findings.summary: Fog implementation is desirable for mood, but it forces everything into 2‑cycle materials, which is “really, really bad” for performance; Kaze references experiencing this tradeoff before in Oily Boily Bay and suspects they may have to accept the cost if it looks good enough.

Kaze attempts to set level-wide fog via Fast64 global fog and a dedicated ‘single triangle’ material approach he reuses across levels; he runs into combiner/material constraints (e.g., current combiner can’t support fog as configured) while iterating.
A major aesthetic breakthrough is realizing the skybox needs to be established early; once the sky/lighting context is set, the same buildings read dramatically better and the course vibe clicks.
findings.quote: This changes the vibe so much… This changes everything. We should have done the sky first.

findings.summary: To keep N64 rendering manageable, Kaze plans the town as a loop around a central mountain (‘reverse donut’) so distant geometry can be culled naturally; this also supports a circular navigation path with multiple route choices.
Kaze rejects making the course ‘story-progression’ driven (like time-of-day shifts across acts), preferring Course 12 to remain a set of disconnected missions rather than another story-heavy level.
After finishing Course 9, development speed dropped because Kaze started working a full-time job, affecting overall momentum and pacing.
findings.quote: Development has slowed down ever since the end of course 9, because I have a full-time job now.

findings.summary: Badub messages Kaze mid-stream with a new Western track (apparently composed for Course 12), and Kaze’s reaction reinforces that music is shaping environmental choices (fog, overall mood) during level conception rather than after the fact.
Kaze’s target tone is intentionally exaggerated and comedic—he explicitly wants a ‘cowboyaboo’ parody approach where the level is stereotypically Western to the point of being knowingly overdone.
findings.quote: I want it to be that, but for cowboys… So, a cowboyaboo.

findings.summary: Additional planned features and references include: Yoshi Valley/Mario Party Western Land inspiration, Twilight Princess hidden village vibe, Wario’s Gold Mine inspiration for train/track spectacle, tumbleweeds/giant cacti, wanted posters, friendly NPC ‘Yoshi cowboys’ (or cowboy Toads), and a potential Yoshi horse farm with ambiguous ‘are Yoshis horses or workers’ comedy.

biobak.summary: Biobak pushes Kaze toward a more saturated/colorful building approach and notes the look is reminiscent of Odyssey-style towns, prompting Kaze to clarify he wants ‘goofy’ without turning the palette into ‘color vomit.’

badub.summary: Badub delivers a newly made Course 12 music track during the stream; Kaze immediately tests it against the level visuals and uses it to justify adding fog/atmospheric effects.

zeina.summary: Zeina briefly appears indirectly (Kaze notes she arrived home during the stream), but no direct art or animation updates are discussed here.

findings.summary: Lilaa suggests using 3D fence/rail styling similar to elements in earlier courses and participates in color/style feedback during the building palette exploration.
Provides a donation that triggers a song request segment; this functions as background while Kaze continues art-style exploration.
Donates and asks for cowboy songs, reinforcing the stream’s ‘cowboy mood’ and indirectly encouraging Kaze’s thematic commitment.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I want it to be that, but for cowboys. So, a cowboyaboo.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze explains the intended tone: intentionally exaggerated, stereotype-forward Western parody rather than gritty realism.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: This changes the vibe so much… This changes everything. We should have done the sky first.
memorable_quotes.context: A key visual-direction breakthrough: establishing sky/lighting early makes the entire art pass ‘click.’

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I don’t explain this anywhere. Nintendo took all my tutorials down.
memorable_quotes.context: While discussing Fast64/decomp toolchain, Kaze notes lost educational resources due to takedowns—useful for a documentary segment on community knowledge and Nintendo pressure.

key_stories.title: Pitching Course 12 as a comedic ‘outlaw roundup’ cowboy town
key_stories.summary: Kaze outlines Course 12’s theme and defines the town’s identity: a saloon that serves milk, friendly cowboy NPCs, wanted posters, and a sheriff who delegates the mess to the player. The course’s stars are framed as capturing outlaws and physically putting them in jail.
key_stories.challenge: Create a Western level that feels fresh in SM64 while staying readable/playable and strongly themed rather than a generic ‘desert.’
key_stories.process: Kaze compiles references (Twilight Princess, Mario Party Western Land, Wario’s Gold Mine) and writes mission pitches tied to specific buildings (saloon, bank, train). He designs three mini-boss encounters that each culminate in jailing a culprit.
key_stories.outcome: A clear design spine emerges: three ‘outlaw’ bosses as stars + strong town roleplay that begins immediately at spawn (Mario starts facing the jail).
key_stories.key_quote: We need this so that you can get the deeds on what your goal is on this level instantly, and the roleplay starts early.

key_stories.title: The art-style struggle and the ‘skybox first’ realization
key_stories.summary: Kaze repeatedly tests building colors/wood textures and finds the scene either dull (‘monocolor’) or too chaotic (‘color vomit’). After adding a skybox/lighting context, the same assets read far better and the intended ‘goofy cowboy’ vibe becomes achievable.
key_stories.challenge: Find a building palette that pops against sand/canyon textures without becoming oversaturated or un-Mario-like.
key_stories.process: Iterative palette tests, reference searching, and even AI concept art prompts for ‘cartoon/goofy wild west town.’ Kaze then adds a skybox and revisits the palette with the new context.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze commits to proceeding to layout planning (MS Paint map) with the improved visual direction, treating sky/atmosphere as foundational rather than a late-stage polish step.
key_stories.key_quote: This changes the vibe so much… This changes everything.

key_stories.title: Fog looks great, but it may cost performance
key_stories.summary: As the music and canyon visuals come together, Kaze wants fog for mood and depth. He realizes (again, from past experience) that enabling fog pushes materials into 2‑cycle rendering, which is costly on N64 and may force compromise.
key_stories.challenge: Add atmospheric depth while keeping the level performant and within N64 rendering constraints.
key_stories.process: Tests global fog via Fast64 and a ‘single triangle’ fog-setting material approach; experiments with fog colors (blue vs orange/yellow). Evaluates how fog interacts with chosen combiners.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze favors the look but flags a major technical risk: widespread 2‑cycle materials, likely repeating issues from Oily Boily Bay.
key_stories.key_quote: Unfortunately, this means everything is going to be a 2-cycle material. Which is really, really bad.

key_stories.title: Designing the town loop around a mountain for culling and flow
key_stories.summary: While sketching the town layout, Kaze chooses a circular route around a central mountain (‘reverse donut’) so large portions of the level can be hidden from view, helping culling and giving the town a coherent ‘wrapped’ structure.
key_stories.challenge: Make a town area feel sizable while ensuring N64-friendly visibility and navigation.
key_stories.process: MS Paint overhead planning: place jail at spawn, define valley entrance vs train station on opposite ends, and propose a central mountain with a tunnel concept (saloon tunnel vs train tunnel).
key_stories.outcome: A performance-informed layout direction that also supports multiple routes and the train as a constant visual element.
key_stories.key_quote: If there’s a huge thing in the middle, we can cut everything that’s far away. So what if this whole city was kind of around a mountain?

key_stories.title: Badub’s music arrives and reshapes atmosphere decisions
key_stories.summary: Badub sends a new track during the stream, and Kaze immediately auditions it and rethinks atmosphere (fog, mood) around it. The music’s identity becomes part of the visual target rather than a late add-on.
key_stories.challenge: Lock in an atmosphere that matches the intended level tone and supports the art direction choices.
key_stories.process: Kaze plays the track on stream, evaluates how it feels with canyon visuals, and discusses fog and ‘vibe’ adjustments in response to the music.
key_stories.outcome: Music becomes a driver for environmental decisions, and Kaze becomes more confident moving to the next production step (layout/blockout).
key_stories.key_quote: Oh, that’s so perfect. I love this.

open_questions.context: Kaze promises a train that can be ridden to fast travel between Area 1 and Area 3, and he also wants the train to have constant presence (e.g., passing over spawn). He debates sky tracks vs tunnel tracks to avoid boring traversal.
questions: Is the train an actual moving platform the player rides, a cutscene/warp, or both depending on station interaction?
How do you prevent train traversal from being ‘boring’ while still feeling like a train (no derailing/platforming contradictions)?
What technical system runs the train (pathing, collision, camera behavior, despawn/respawn across areas)?
Did you end up implementing both valley-level tracks and sky-level tracks, and how did that affect readability/performance?

open_questions.context: Each of the three outlaw encounters is planned to award a star and end with putting the culprit in jail.
questions: How is ‘putting them in jail’ represented mechanically—escort, scripted teleport, post-star cutscene, or persistent NPC state?
How do you keep three boss encounters in one course from feeling repetitive in SM64’s mission structure?
Were any of these bosses cut, merged, or moved to other areas during production?

open_questions.context: Kaze likes fog aesthetically but notes it forces 2‑cycle materials and may hurt performance, recalling prior pain in Oily Boily Bay.
questions: What performance hit did 2‑cycle fog actually cause on hardware/accurate emulators, and where did it show up (FPS, pop-in, input feel)?
Did you find a workaround (selective fog materials, alternate combiner, distance culling, reduced geometry, texture changes)?
How do you decide when ‘it looks so good we take the loss’ is acceptable?

open_questions.context: Kaze realizes the skybox should be set early because it changes how all materials/colors read.
questions: What is your skybox workflow in decomp/Fast64 (assets, resolution, memory constraints)?
Do you now set skybox/lighting earlier for later courses because of this lesson?
How do you coordinate sky/fog/music so they reinforce the same ‘tone’?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions Fast64 exporting to decomp and that Nintendo removed his tutorials, leaving a gap for newcomers.
questions: Which tutorials were taken down, and when—what impact did that have on community onboarding or contributor recruitment?
Did you replace the tutorials with private docs/Discord guidance, or rely on community re-uploads?
How do legal pressures shape what you publish publicly about ROM hacking vs decomp-based projects?

open_questions.topic: Course 12 layout evolution and performance-driven design
open_questions.context: Kaze chooses a ‘reverse donut’ town around a central mountain primarily for culling/visibility control.
questions: Did the central mountain/culling plan survive to the final version, and what changed during blockout?
What metrics or heuristics do you use to decide when a layout is ‘safe’ for N64 rendering?
How often do art goals lose to performance constraints at this stage?

open_questions.context: Late in the stream, Kaze reveals Area 2 includes a scavenger hunt: signs give hints that chain to the next location, framed as a movement playground.
questions: What are the scavenger hunt steps, and how do you communicate them (sign text, NPCs, environmental cues)?
How do you prevent players from getting lost or sequence-breaking in an open ‘playground’ area?
Does the scavenger hunt tie into Yoshi Coins or another collectible system?

open_questions.topic: Audio additions beyond music (Yiha sound, NPC audio)
open_questions.context: Kaze considers changing Mario’s jump sound to a ‘yiha’ and possibly giving NPCs silly sounds; dialogue is inspired by the Cowboy Cats account.
questions: What other sound design changes were made to sell the cowboy parody (weapons, tumbleweeds, train)?
How do you implement custom voice/sfx safely within ROM constraints and avoid repetition fatigue?
Did any dialogue inspirations need rewriting to fit in-universe tone or localization?

open_questions.topic: Content scope for the course (karts/minecarts, gold mine, 8-bit area)
open_questions.context: Kaze mentions a gold mine area, mine tracks, and says ‘cards/karts to drive around in’ plus a hidden 8‑bit area in the canyon, but details are not developed on-stream.
questions: Did driving segments (karts/minecarts) make it into the course, and what engine modifications were needed?
How big is the gold mine area relative to the town, and what is its gameplay purpose (star, secrets, traversal hub)?
What is the ‘8-bit area’ mechanically—visual easter egg, retro physics segment, or separate sublevel?

open_questions.context: This stream is primarily Kaze planning/iteration; only Badub’s music arrives explicitly, while art tasks (textures/models/NPCs) are implied but not assigned on-stream.
questions: What did you hand off to Biobak/Zeina after locking the style (specific building kits, textures, NPC models/animations)?
How do you keep style consistent when multiple artists touch the same course?
What feedback loops exist (paintovers, in-engine reviews, revision cycles) and how long do they usually take?
